revision.text:
Statistics of [[Campionato Sammarinese di Calcio]] in season 1988/1989.
==Overview== It was performed in 10 teams, and [[F.C. Domagnano|S.P. Domagnano]] won the championship.
==Regular season== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center;" |Pos||Club||P||W||D||L||GF||GA||Pts||Memo |- ||1||[[A.C. Libertas]]||18||9||7||2||32||14||25||Playoff |- ||2||[[S.P. Juvenes/Dogana|G.S. Dogana]]||18||6||9||3||21||15||21 |- ||6||[[S.S. Folgore/Falciano]]||18||6||7||5||22||19||19 |- ||7||[[S.S. Virtus]]||18||5||7||6||20||25||17 |- ||8||[[S.P. Tre Fiori]]||18||4||7||7||16||18||15 |- ||9||[[S.S. Montevito]]||18||4||3||11||15||37||11||Relegated |- ||10||[[S.S. San Giovanni]]||18||2||2||14||11||38||6||Relegated |}
==Championship Playoff==
===First round=== *[[S.C. Faetano]] 0-0 (pen 4-3) [[F.C. Domagnano]] *[[S.S. Murata]] 2-0 [[S.P. Cailungo]]
===Second round=== *[[F.C. Domagnano]] 0-0 (pen 4-2) [[S.S. Murata]] *[[S.C. Faetano]] 4-1 [[S.P. Cailungo]]
===Third round=== *[[F.C. Domagnano]] 2-0 [[S.S. Murata]] *[[S.P. La Fiorita]] 0-0 (pen 5-4) [[S.C. Faetano]]
===Fourth round=== *[[F.C. Domagnano]] 1-0 [[S.C. Faetano]] *[[S.P. La Fiorita]] 1-0 [[A.C. Libertas]]
===Semifinal=== *[[A.C. Libertas]] 0-1 [[F.C. Domagnano]]
===Final=== *[[F.C. Domagnano]] 2-1 [[S.P. La Fiorita]]
==References== *[http://www.rsssf.com/tabless/sanmchamp.html San Marino - List of final tables (RSSSF)]

{{Infobox Athletics Championships |Name = 42nd South American Championships |Logo = |Size = |Optional caption = |Colour = #A9F5A9 |Host city = [[Barquisimeto]], [[Venezuela]]{{flagicon|Venezuela|1930}} |Dates = 20–22 June 2003 |Stadium = [[Polideportivo Máximo Viloria]] |Nations participating = 12 |Athletes participating = 296 |Events = 44 |Records set = 8 [[List of South American Championships in Athletics records|Championships records]] |Previous = [[2001 South American Championships in Athletics|2001 Manaus]] |Next = [[2005 South American Championships in Athletics|2005 Cali]] }} The '''2003 [[South American Championships in Athletics]]''' were held from June 20 to June 22 at the [[Polideportivo Máximo Viloria]] {{ Citation | last = EFE | first = | date = Feb 20, 2003 | title = Ciudad venezolana de Barquisimeto postula a sede Sudamericano | url = http://wvw.nacion.com/ln_ee/2003/febrero/20/udeporgen-mu4.html | publisher = La Nación S.A. | language = Spanish | accessdate = November 9, 2011 }} {{ Citation | last = Biscayart | first = Eduardo | date = June 19, 2003 | title = Venezuela to host Historic South American Championships | url = http://www.iaaf.org/news/news/venezuela-to-host-historic-south-american-cha | publisher = [[IAAF]] | accessdate = November 8, 2011 }} in [[Barquisimeto]], [[Venezuela]]. {{about|the 2012–13 ice sports season and results|other sports' results|2013 in sports}} {{Year box}} {{Year nav topic5|2013|ice sports}}
==[[Bandy]]== ===World Championship=== * January 27 – February 3: [[2013 Bandy World Championship]] in {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Vänersborg]] ** Division A: {{bandy|RUS}} defeated {{bandy|SWE}}, 4–3, to win their seventh overall Bandy World Championship title. {{bandy|KAZ}} took the bronze medal. ** Division B: {{bandy|USA}} defeated {{bandy|CAN}}, 4–2, in the final, and is qualified for Division A next year. {{bandy|LAT}} took third place.
===World Cup=== * Final game, [[2012 Bandy World Cup]], October: [[Zorky Krasnogorsk]] (Russia) defeated [[Yenisey Krasnoyarsk Bandy Club|Yenisey Krasnoyarsk]] (Russia), 3–0
===World Cup Women=== * Final game, 2012 Bandy World Cup Women, October: won by [[Rekord Irkutsk]] (Russia)
===National champions=== * [[List of Finnish bandy champions|Finland]]: [[HIFK Bandy|Helsinki IFK]] (men), [[Veitsiluodon Vastus]] (women) * [[List of Norwegian bandy champions|Norway]]: [[Ullevål IL]] (men), [[Drammen Bandy]] (women) * [[List of Russian bandy champions|Russia]]: [[Dynamo Moscow Bandy Club|Dynamo Moscow]] (men) * [[List of Swedish bandy champions|Sweden]]: [[Hammarby IF Bandy|Hammarby IF]] (men), [[Sandvikens AIK]] (women) * [[List of Ukrainian bandy champions|Ukraine]]: [[Avangard Budy]] (men) * [[List of United States bandy champions|United States]]: [[Dynamo Duluth]] (men)
===International Youth Championships=== * [[Bandy World Championship G-17|G17 World Championship]] ** Winner: {{flagicon|SWE}} Sweden * [[Bandy World Championship Y-17|U17 World Championship]] ** Winner: {{flagicon|FIN}} Finland * [[Bandy World Championship Y-23|U23 World Championship]] ** Winner: {{flagicon|RUS}} Russia
==[[Bobsleigh]] and [[Skeleton (sport)|skeleton]]==
* [[2012–13 Bobsleigh World Cup]] **Two-man overall winner: {{flagicon|CAN}} [[Lyndon Rush]] **Four-man overall winner: {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Alexandr Zubkov]] **Two-women overall winner: {{flagicon|CAN}} [[Kaillie Humphries]] * [[2012–13 Skeleton World Cup]] **Men's overall winner: {{flagicon|LAT}} [[Martins Dukurs]] **Women's overall winner: {{flagicon|GER}} [[Marion Thees]] * The [[FIBT World Championships 2013]] took place at the [[St. Moritz-Celerina Olympic Bobrun]] at [[St. Moritz]], [[Switzerland]]. **Two-man bobsleigh winner: {{flagicon|GER}} [[Francesco Friedrich]] / [[Jannis Bäcker]] **Four-man bobsleigh winner: {{flagicon|GER}} [[Maximilian Arndt]] / [[Marko Hübenbecker]] / [[Alexander Rödiger]] / [[Martin Putze]] **Two-women bobsleigh winner: {{flagicon|CAN}} [[Kaillie Humphries]] / [[Chelsea Valois]] **Men's skeleton winner: {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Aleksandr Tretyakov (skeleton racer)|Aleksandr Tretyakov]] **Women's skeleton winner: {{flagicon|GBR}} [[Shelley Rudman]]
==[[Curling]]==
;Season of Champions *'''[[2012 Canada Cup of Curling|Canada Cup of Curling]]''' ([[Moose Jaw]], Saskatchewan, November 28 – December 2) **Men's winner: {{flagicon|MB}} '''[[Jeff Stoughton]]''' def. {{flagicon|ON}} [[Glenn Howard]] **Women's winner: {{flagicon|SK}} '''[[Stefanie Lawton]]''' def. {{flagicon|MB}} [[Kaitlyn Lawes]] *[[2013 Continental Cup of Curling|Continental Cup of Curling]] ([[Penticton, British Columbia|Penticton]], British Columbia, 10–13 January) **Winner: Team North America *[[2013 Canadian Junior Curling Championships|M&M Meat Shops Canadian Junior Curling Championships]] ([[Fort McMurray]], Alberta, 31 January – 10 February) **Men's winner: {{MB}} ([[Matt Dunstone]], skip) **Women's winner: {{BC}} ([[Corryn Brown]], skip) *[[2013 Scotties Tournament of Hearts|Scotties Tournament of Hearts]] ([[Kingston, Ontario|Kingston]], Ontario, 16–24 February) **Winner: {{ON}} ([[Rachel Homan]], skip) *[[2013 Tim Hortons Brier|Tim Hortons Brier]] ([[Edmonton]], Alberta, March 2–10) **Winner: {{NO}} ([[Brad Jacobs (curler)|Brad Jacobs]], skip)
;Grand slams *'''[[2012 Curlers Corner Autumn Gold Curling Classic|Curlers Corner Autumn Gold Curling Classic]]''' ([[Calgary]], Alberta, October 5–8) **Women's winner: {{flagicon|ON}} '''[[Sherry Middaugh]]''' def. {{flagicon|ON}} [[Rachel Homan]] *'''[[2012 Manitoba Lotteries Women's Curling Classic|Manitoba Lotteries Women's Curling Classic]]''' ([[Winnipeg]], Manitoba, October 19–22) **Women's winner: {{flagicon|SK}} '''[[Stefanie Lawton]]''' def. {{flagicon|ON}} [[Rachel Homan]] *'''[[2012 Colonial Square Ladies Classic|Colonial Square Ladies Classic]]''' ([[Saskatoon]], Saskatchewan, November 9–12) **Women's winner: {{flagicon|SK}} '''[[Stefanie Lawton]]''' def. {{flagicon|MB}} [[Chelsea Carey]] *'''[[The Masters Grand Slam of Curling]]''' ([[Brantford]], Ontario, November 14–18) **Men's winner: {{flagicon|AB}} '''[[Kevin Koe]]''' def. {{flagicon|BC}} [[Jim Cotter (curler)|Jim Cotter]] **Women's winner: {{flagicon|ON}} '''[[Rachel Homan]]''' def. {{flagicon|MB}} [[Chelsea Carey]] *'''[[BDO Canadian Open of Curling|Canadian Open of Curling]]''' ([[Kelowna]], British Columbia, December 12–16) **Men's winner: {{flagicon|ON}} '''[[Glenn Howard]]''' def. {{flagicon|ON}} [[Brad Jacobs (curler)|Brad Jacobs]] *[[2013 The National|The Pomeroy Inn & Suites National]] ([[Port Hawkesbury]], Nova Scotia, 23–27 January) **Winner: {{flagicon|MB}} [[Jeff Stoughton]] (skip) *[[Players' Championship|The Players' Championship]] ([[Toronto]], Ontario, April 16–21) **Men's winner: {{flagicon|ON}} [[Glenn Howard]] **Women's winner: {{flagicon|SCO}} [[Eve Muirhead]]
;World championships *[[2013 World Wheelchair Curling Championship|World Wheelchair Curling Championship]] ([[Sochi]], Russia, 16–23 February) **Winner: {{CAN}} ([[Jim Armstrong (curler)|Jim Armstrong]], skip) *[[2013 World Junior Curling Championships|World Junior Curling Championships]] ([[Sochi]], Russia, 28 February – 10 March) **Men's winner: {{SCO}} ([[Kyle Smith (curler)|Kyle Smith]], skip) **Women's winner: {{RUS}} ([[Alina Kovaleva]], skip) *[[2013 World Women's Curling Championship|World Women's Curling Championship]] ([[Riga]], Latvia, March 16–24) **Winner: {{SCO}} ([[Eve Muirhead]], skip)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wwcc2013.curlingevents.com/wwcc-2013-scotland-win-gold|title=Scotland wins gold|publisher=[[World Curling Federation]]|accessdate=2013-03-24|date=2013-03-24|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130327044629/http://wwcc2013.curlingevents.com/wwcc-2013-scotland-win-gold|archive-date=2013-03-27|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *[[2013 Ford World Men's Curling Championship|World Men's Curling Championship]] ([[Victoria, British Columbia|Victoria]], British Columbia, March 30 – April 7) ** Winner: {{SWE}} ([[Niklas Edin]], skip) *[[2013 World Senior Curling Championships|World Senior Curling Championships]] ([[Fredericton]], New Brunswick, April 13–20) ** Men's winner: {{CAN}} ([[Rob Armitage]], skip) ** Women's winner: {{CAN}} ([[Cathy King]], skip) *[[2013 World Mixed Doubles Curling Championship|World Mixed Doubles Curling Championship]] ([[Fredericton]], New Brunswick, April 13–20) ** Winner: {{HUN}} Zsolt Kiss / Dorottya Palancsa
==[[Figure skating]]==
* 21–27 January: [[2013 European Figure Skating Championships]] in [[Zagreb]], [[Croatia]] **Men: '''{{flagicon|ESP}} [[Javier Fernández (figure skater)|Javier Fernandez]]''' (first title).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isuresults.com/results/ec2013/SEG002.HTM|title=Results|publisher=ISU|accessdate=26 January 2013}}</ref> **Ladies: '''{{flagicon|ITA}} [[Carolina Kostner]]''' (fifth title).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.isuresults.com/results/ec2013/CAT002RS.HTM|title=Results|publisher=ISU|accessdate=26 January 2013}}</ref> **Pairs: '''{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Tatiana Volosozhar]] / [[Maxim Trankov]]''' (second title). **Ice dance: '''{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Ekaterina Bobrova]] / [[Dmitri Soloviev]]''' (first title). * 5–10 February: [[2013 Four Continents Figure Skating Championships]] in [[Osaka]], [[Japan]] **Men: '''{{flagicon|CAN}} [[Kevin Reynolds (figure skater)|Kevin Reynolds]]''' (first title).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.isu.org/vsite/vnavsite/page/directory/0,10853,4844-205151-222374-nav-list,00.html?id=1258|title=Reynolds skates to Gold|publisher=ISU|accessdate=9 February 2013}}</ref> **Ladies: '''{{flagicon|JPN}} [[Mao Asada]]''' (third title).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.isu.org/vsite/vnavsite/page/directory/0,10853,4844-205151-222374-nav-list,00.html?id=1259|title=Asada takes Gold|publisher=ISU|accessdate=10 February 2013}}</ref> **Pairs: '''{{flagicon|CAN}} [[Meagan Duhamel]] / [[Eric Radford]]''' (first title). **Ice dance: '''{{flagicon|USA}} [[Meryl Davis]] / [[Charlie White (figure skater)|Charlie White]]''' (third title). * 25 February – 3 March: [[2013 World Junior Figure Skating Championships]] in [[Milan]], [[Italy]] **Men: '''{{flagicon|USA}} [[Joshua Farris]]''' (first title). **Ladies: '''{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Elena Radionova]]''' (first title). **Pairs: '''{{flagicon|USA}} [[Haven Denney]] / [[Brandon Frazier]]''' (first title). **Ice dance: '''{{flagicon|RUS}} [[Alexandra Stepanova]] / [[Ivan Bukin]]''' (first title). * March 10 – 17: [[2013 World Figure Skating Championships]] in [[London, Ontario|London]], Ontario, [[Canada]] **Men: '''{{flagicon|CAN}} [[Patrick Chan]]''' (third consecutive title).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www2.isu.org/vsite/vnavsite/page/directory/0,10853,4844-205151-222374-nav-list,00.html?id=1292|title=Chan captures gold medal|publisher=ISU|accessdate=15 March 2013}}</ref> **Ladies: '''{{flagicon|KOR}} [[Yuna Kim]]''' (second title). **Pairs: '''{{flagicon|RUS}}''' '''[[Tatiana Volosozhar]] / [[Maxim Trankov]]''' (first title). **Ice dance: '''{{flagicon|USA}} [[Meryl Davis]] / [[Charlie White (figure skater)|Charlie White]]''' (second title). * April 11 – 14: [[2013 ISU World Team Trophy in Figure Skating]] in [[Tokyo]] **Team Champions: {{USA}}; Second: {{CAN}}; Third: {{JPN}}
==[[Ice hockey]]==
* 26 December – 5 January: [[2013 World Junior Ice Hockey Championships]] in [[Russia]] **The {{ihj|USA}} defeated defending champion {{ihj|SWE}} 3–1 to win their third title. [[John Gibson (ice hockey b. 1993)|John Gibson]] was named MVP of the tournament.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.worldjunior2013.com/en/channels/2013/wm20/top/news/swe-usa/|title=U.S. golden in Ufa|publisher=IIHF.com|accessdate=5 January 2013}}</ref> * 29 December – 5 January: [[2013 IIHF World Women's U18 Championship]] in Finland **{{ihw18|CAN}} defeats the {{ihw18|USA}} 2–1 in [[Overtime (ice hockey)|overtime]] to win their third title. * April 2 – 9: [[2013 IIHF Women's World Championship]] in [[Canada]] **The {{ihw|USA}} defeated {{ihw|CAN}} 3–2 to claim its fifth title in this championship. * April 18 – 28: [[2013 IIHF World U18 Championships]] in Russia **{{ih18|CAN}} defeats the {{ih18|USA}} 3–2 to claim its third title in this event. * May 3 – 19: [[2013 IIHF World Championship]] in [[Sweden]] and [[Finland]] **{{ih|SWE}} defeated {{ih|SUI}} 5–1 to win its ninth title for this championship. {{flagicon|SUI}} [[Roman Josi]], of the NHL's [[Nashville Predators]], was named MVP of the tournament. * June 12 – 24: [[2013 Stanley Cup Finals]]<ref>[http://www.nhl.com/ice/news.htm?id=673375 NHL's 2013 Stanley Cup Final Schedule]</ref> ** Winner: {{flagicon|Illinois}} [[2012–13 Chicago Blackhawks season|Chicago Blackhawks]] (fifth title).
==[[Luge]]==
* 24 November 2012 – 24 February 2013: [[2012–13 Luge World Cup]] ** {{GER}} won all the gold medals in the four events for this sport. * 1–2 February: The [[FIL World Luge Championships 2013]] were held at the [[Whistler Sliding Centre]] in [[Canada]] ** {{GER}} won the gold and overall medal tallies.
==Short-track speed skating==
* 19 October 2012 – 12 February 2013: [[2012–13 ISU Short Track Speed Skating World Cup]] ** {{KOR}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. * March 8 – 10: The [[2013 World Short Track Speed Skating Championships]] took place at the [[Főnix Hall]], in [[Debrecen]], [[Hungary]] ** {{KOR}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies.
==Speed skating (long-track)==
* 16 November 2012 – 10 March 2013: [[2012–13 ISU Speed Skating World Cup]] ** {{NED}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies. * 26–27 January: The [[2013 World Sprint Speed Skating Championships]] were held at the [[Utah Olympic Oval]], in [[Salt Lake City]], United States ** Men's winner: {{flagicon|NED}} [[Michel Mulder]] (first title). ** Women's winner: {{flagicon|USA}} [[Heather Richardson-Bergsma|Heather Richardson]] (first title). * 15–16 February: The [[2013 World Allround Speed Skating Championships]] were held at the [[Vikingskipet]] (Hamar Olympic Hall), in [[Hamar]], Norway ** Men's winner: {{flagicon|NED}} [[Sven Kramer]] (sixth title). ** Women's winner: {{flagicon|NED}} [[Ireen Wüst]] (fourth title). * 21–24 March: The [[2013 World Single Distance Speed Skating Championships]] were held at the [[Adler Arena Skating Center]], in [[Sochi]], Russia ** {{NED}} won both the gold and overall medal tallies.

[[Zouérate]], [[Mauritania]] | capacity = 1000| chairman = |1980 manager = | league = [[Mauritanean Premier League]] | season = 2013-14 | position = | }} '''ASC Kédia''' is a [[Mauritania|Mauritanean]] [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Zouérat]] the capital of the [[Tiris Zemmour]] region. The club plays in the [[Mauritanean Premier League]].{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/teams/mauritania/asc-kedia/13044/matches/|title=Mauritania - ASC Kédia - Risultati e calendario - Soccerway|publisher=it.soccerway.com|accessdate=2014-02-22}} ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 1000 capacity [[Stade Municipal Zouérate]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/mauritania/asc-kedia/13044/ Soccerway] *{{cite web|url=http://sports.opera.com/?sport=soccer&page=team&id=13044&p=-1&localization_id=it|title=ASC Kédia - Calcio - Opera mobile - Results, fixtures, tables and statistics|publisher=sports.opera.com|accessdate=2014-02-22}} {{Mauritanean Premier League}} {{DEFAULTSORT:ASC Kedia}} [[Category:Football clubs in Mauritania]] {{Mauritania-footyclub-stub}}

page.title: Alerding v. Ohio High School Athletic Association

revision.comment: added [[Category:United States education case law]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox court case |name = ''Alerding v. Ohio High School Athletic Association'' |court = [[United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit]] |image = |imagesize = |caption = |full name = F. Dennis Alerding, individually and as next friend of Dennis C. Alerding, a minor; and Roger H. Moellering, individually and as next friend of David R. Moellering, Douglas R. Moellering and Gregory R. Moellering, minors, Plaintiffs-Appellants, v. Ohio High School Athletic Association; Richard L. Armstrong, Commissioner, Ohio High School Athletic Association and St. Xavier High School, Defendants-Appellees |date decided = {{Start date|1985|12|17}} |citations = 779 F.2d 315 (6th Cir. 1985) |transcripts = |judges = [[Albert J. Engel Jr.]], [[Robert B. Krupansky]], [[John Weld Peck II]] |prior actions = The [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio|District court]] denied the plaintiffs' requests for relief. |opinions = The district court ruling was affirmed. |keywords = [[Privileges and Immunities Clause]] |decision by = [[John Weld Peck II]] |number of judges = 3 |appealed from = [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio]] }}
'''''Alerding v. Ohio High School Athletic Association'''''<ref name="Alerding">{{cite court|litigants=Alerding v. Ohio High School Athletic Association|vol=779|reporter=F.2d|opinion=315|court=6th Cir.|date=December 17, 1985|url=https://law.resource.org/pub/us/case/reporter/F2/779/779.F2d.315.84-3787.html|accessdate=January 13, 2015}}</ref> was a court case heard before the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit]] which held that the right to participate in [[Student athlete|interscholastic sports]] is not a fundamental privilege protected by the [[Privileges and Immunities Clause]] of the [[United States Constitution]]. In particular, the court held that the [[Ohio High School Athletic Association]] could prohibit private high school athletic programs from recruiting students who live in neighboring states.
==Background== Virtually every [[List of high schools in Ohio|secondary school]] in [[Ohio]], whether public or private, is a member of the [[Ohio High School Athletic Association]] (OHSAA), which regulates interscholastic sports within the state.<ref name="Alerding" /> By the 1970s, private member schools often dominated state championships, even though they made up only about a quarter of OHSAA's 800 members. Public member schools complained that private schools in border cities were recruiting out-of-state students for varsity sports, giving them a competitive edge over public schools.<ref name="Alerding" /><ref name="Enquirer Kaufman">{{cite news|title=Judge Requests More Information On Athletes' Ban|first=Ben L.|last=Kaufman|work=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]|date=June 5, 1984|page=C2|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/100737403/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> The association's rule against recruiting or "school hopping" was difficult to enforce against private schools that could enroll students regardless of residence. There was a rule requiring transfer students to wait one year before joining a team, but that usually left three years of play.<ref name="Enquirer Kaufman" />
On December 18, 1978, OHSAA's 661 member schools defeated a proposal that would have split schools into separate divisions for the 564 public schools and 97 parochial and private schools.<ref name="Enquirer Holtz">{{cite news|title=Out-Of-State Into Court|first=Randy|last=Holtz|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=August 15, 1980|page=C4|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/101410107/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Parochial, Private School Division Split Considered|first=Ray|last=Buck|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=June 15, 1978|page=D1|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/101637124/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> Instead, they voted 65.1% in favor of adopting [[By-law|bylaw]] 4, section 6.4–6.10 (originally known as rule 92G), which states in part: "A student whose parents live in another state will be ineligible for athletics in an Ohio member school."<ref name="Dover">{{cite news|title=Prep out-of-state rule tested|agency=Associated Press|location=Dover, Ohio|work=[[The Times-Reporter]]|volume=81|issue=75|date=October 5, 1983|page=C-2|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/dover-times-reporter-oct-05-1983-p-14/|via=NewspaperARCHIVE}}</ref><ref name="District" /> The rule took effect for incoming ninth graders in July 1979. It primarily affected schools in [[Cincinnati]] and [[Toledo, Ohio|Toledo]], where out-of-state athletes had traditionally competed.<ref name="Enquirer Holtz" /> In the Cincinnati area, the new rule affected [[St. Xavier High School (Cincinnati)|St. Xavier High School]], [[Moeller High School]], [[Summit Country Day School]], [[Cincinnati Country Day School]], and [[Seven Hills School]].<ref name="Enquirer Paolercio imported">{{cite news|title=Imported Athletes Kept Out|first=Michael|last=Paolercio|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=September 30, 1980|page=A1|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/101210177/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref>
[[File:St. Xavier High School (Cincinnati), stadium entrance.jpg|thumb|left|The flags of three states fly outside St. Xavier's football stadium.]]
Unlike the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Cincinnati|Archdiocese of Cincinnati]]'s interparochial high schools, St. Xavier was a [[Society of Jesus|Jesuit]] school not subject to parochial boundaries; it drew students from nearby communities in Southeastern Indiana and [[Northern Kentucky]] in addition to Southwestern Ohio.<ref name="Alerding" /><ref name="Dover" /> In the 1950s, up to a third of St. Xavier students were Kentuckians.<ref name="Enquirer Pulfer">{{cite news|title=Court Upholds High School Ban Against Non-Ohio Athletes|first1=Mike|last1=Pulfer|first2=Ben L.|last2=Kaufman|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=December 18, 1985|page=C1, C6|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/101770582/|via=Newspapers.com}}<!-- https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/101770597/--></ref> Some of St. Xavier's most best-known alumni were star athletes while living in Kentucky, including [[Jim Bunning]], [[Bob Arnzen]], and [[Charles Wolf (basketball)|Charlie Wolf]].<ref>{{cite news|title=St. X Tradition Dies Bitterly in N. Ky.|first=Michael|last=Paolercio|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=September 30, 1980|page=C1|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/101210278/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref name="Enquirer Paolercio imported" /> By the 1980s, St. Xavier competed in several sports at the Division I level and had won numerous district football and tennis titles and several state swimming championships.<ref name="Champs">{{cite web|title=St. Xavier High School Athletic Champions|publisher=St. Xavier High School|url=http://www.stxavier.org/s/106/stxavier.aspx?pgid=1403|accessdate=January 8, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080123201929/http://www.stxavier.org/s/106/stxavier.aspx?pgid=1403|archivedate=January 23, 2008}}</ref>
In 1980, the parents of eight Northern Kentucky students who had been admitted to St. Xavier, including Tom Menke and Danny Mueller, sued OHSAA in Hamilton County [[Ohio Courts of Common Pleas|Court of Common Pleas]] because the students would be banned from competition under bylaw 4-6-10. The common pleas court let the rule stand, and a [[Ohio District Courts of Appeals|state appellate court]] upheld the decision in September 1981.<ref>{{cite court|litigants=Menke v. Ohio High School Athletic Association|vol=2|reporter=Ohio App.3d|opinion=244|court=Ct.App. Hamilton Cty.|date=September 16, 1981|url=https://www.leagle.com/decision/19812462ohioapp3d2441175}}</ref><ref name="Enquirer Gutsell">{{cite news|title=Ruling Will Let Kentuckians Play On Ohio School Teams|first=Jeff|last=Gutsell|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=November 19, 1983|page=C2|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/101717199/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Ban On Out-Of-Staters Upheld|first=Michael|last=Paolercio|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=September 17, 1981|page=D6|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/103149543/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref>
Dennis C. Alerding resided in [[Fort Thomas, Kentucky]], and attended St. Xavier as a sophomore. Three Moellering brothers lived in [[Lakeside Park, Kentucky]], and also attended St. Xavier: David R., a junior, Douglas R., a sophomore, and Gregory R., a freshman. All were ineligible to participate in the school's athletic programs due to bylaw 4-6-10.<ref name="Enquirer Howard">{{cite news|title=OHSAA Out-Of-State Rule Tested in Court|first=Allen|last=Howard|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=October 5, 1983|page=B4|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/103326822/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Was OHSAA unfair in banning 4 players?|agency=Associated Press|work=[[BG News]]|location=Bowling Green, Ohio|volume=68|issue=16|date=September 20, 1985|page=7|url=https://scholarworks.bgsu.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=5421&context=bg-news#page=8|format=PDF}}</ref> Alerding practiced with the wrestling team but could not participate in meets, while David Moellering had wanted to play baseball or basketball.<ref name="Enquirer Pulfer" /> In October 1983, their fathers, F. Dennis Alerding and Roger H. Moellering, filed suit against OHSAA and St. Xavier in the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio]], alleging that the bylaw violated the four students' constitutional right to a complete education. They sought a temporary [[injunction]] before the end of the winter athletic season and a [[declaratory judgment]] against the ban. The plaintiffs noted that ''Menke'' did not concern the constitutionality of the bylaw<ref name="Enquirer Gutsell" /> and cited a passage in the OHSAA constitution, which read in part: "Competitive sports are an inherent part of the total education program for students in secondary schools."<ref name="Alerding" /><ref name="Dover" />
==Legal proceedings== The case came before the [[United States District Court for the Southern District of Ohio]]. On November 23, 1983, Judge [[S. Arthur Spiegel]] denied the temporary restraining order because Alerding and Moellering would have known about the ban prior to enrolling their sons at St. Xavier, and because the order would have forced part of the 1983–84 season to be played under temporary rules.<ref>{{cite news|title=Students Lose 1st Bid To Play In Ohio|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=November 23, 1983|page=A8|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/101717738/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> On June 5, 1984, Judge Spiegel heard the case for three hours, then asked attorneys for the plaintiffs to return with information on how [[Michigan]], Indiana, Kentucky, [[West Virginia]], and [[Pennsylvania]] treat out-of-state student-athletes.<ref name="Enquirer Kaufman" />
On August 20, 1984, the district court found that the OHSAA bylaw could be considered a state action. However, citing ''[[San Antonio Independent School District v. Rodriguez]]'' and the recent ''[[United Building & Construction Trades Council v. Mayor and Council of Camden|Camden]]'' case, the court ruled that interscholastic high school athletics was not protected by the Privileges and Immunities Clause, reasoning that school athletics pales in comparison to the employment opportunities that the clause often concerns. Given that the courts had ruled educational opportunity not to be a fundamental privilege, extracurricular activities could not be considered fundamental either. The court acknowledged that educational opportunities may be a prerequisite for employment opportunities, but considered the impact of the bylaw to be a matter of degree. Based on these findings, the court denied the plaintiffs' requests for an injunction and declaratory judgment.<ref name="District">{{cite court|litigants=Alerding v. Ohio High School Athletic Association|vol=591|reporter=F.Supp.|opinion=1538|court=S.D. Ohio|date=August 20, 1984|accessdate=May 20, 2018|url=https://law.justia.com/cases/federal/district-courts/FSupp/591/1538/2388721/}}</ref>
In response, State Representative [[Dave Karmol]] of Toledo introduced a bill that would have prohibited OHSAA from considering a student's state of residence in determining eligibility. Karmol said that Toledo-area schools, both public and private, supported the measure, but the bill did not advance.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bill Hits At Out-Of-State Recruiting Ban|first=Randy|last=Holtz|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=June 12, 1980|page=D6|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/101633824/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref>
Alerding and Moellering appealed to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Sixth Circuit]], arguing that ''Rodriguez'' pertained to the [[Equal Protection Clause]] rather than the Privileges and Immunities Clause, and that the court should consider instead whether the bylaw was related to OHSAA's objective of eliminating unfair recruiting. On December 17, 1985, the appellate court disagreed with both aspects of the appeal and affirmed the district court's ruling, allowing OHSAA's bylaw to stand.<ref name="Alerding" /> By then, St. Xavier had 1,250 students, and the number of students from Kentucky had fallen to 35. St. Xavier principal Michael Trainor predicted that the ruling would further weaken St. Xavier's Kentucky enrollment despite strong historical family loyalties to the school there.<ref name="Enquirer Pulfer" />
Around the same time as the ''Alerding'' case, John W. and Judy Zeiler of [[Bedford Township, Monroe County, Michigan]], sued OHSAA before the [[United States District Court for the Northern District of Ohio]] on behalf of their three children who attended [[Central Catholic High School (Toledo, Ohio)|Central Catholic High School]] in [[Toledo, Ohio|Toledo]], along with 32 other Michigan children.<ref>{{cite court|litigants=Zeiler v. Ohio High School Athletic Association|opinion=slip. op. 83-765|court=N.D.Ohio|date=February 3, 1984}}</ref><ref name="Enquirer Gutsell" /><ref>{{cite news|title=Family Commutes Across State Line for Sports|agency=Associated Press|work=[[The Palm Beach Post]]|date=March 5, 1985|page=C3|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/129677260/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref name="Enquirer restraining">{{cite news|title=Federal Judge Continues Order Against OHSAA|agency=Associated Press|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=October 15, 1983|page=B4|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/103327953/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref> [[John William Potter]] of the district court granted a temporary restraining order,<ref name="Enquirer restraining" /> but the court ultimately allowed bylaw 4-6-10 to stand; this ruling was upheld without comment by the [[Supreme Court of the United States|United States Supreme Court]] in 1985.<ref>{{cite court|litigants=John W. Zeiler, et al. v. Ohio High School Athletic Association, et al.|opinion=slip op. 84-1671|court=U.S.|date=October 7, 1985|page=17|url=https://www.supremecourt.gov/pdfs/journals/scannedjournals/1985_journal.pdf|format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Non-Residents Still Fighting OHSAA Ruling|work=The Cincinnati Enquirer|date=October 9, 1985|page=E8|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/101442594/|via=Newspapers.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Court tackles affirmative action|agency=United Press International|location=Defiance, Ohio|work=The Crescent-News|page=3|date=October 8, 1985|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/defiance-crescent-news-oct-08-1985-p-15/|via=NewspaperARCHIVE}}</ref>
==Impact== ''Alerding'' has been cited in later cases to show that the actions of state high school athletic associations, such as OHSAA, are considered to be state action.<ref>{{cite court|litigants=Alston v. Virginia High School League|vol=144|reporter=F.Supp. 2d|opinion=526|court=W.D. Va.|date=1999|page=19|url=http://www.vawd.uscourts.gov/opinions/michael/397cv095msj.pdf#page=21|format=PDF}}</ref>
OHSAA bylaw 4-6-10 barring out-of-state students remains in effect.<ref>{{cite web|title=Residence Bylaw Resource Center|publisher=Ohio High School Athletic Association|accessdate=May 20, 2018|url=http://www.ohsaa.org/Eligibility/Residence-Bylaw-Resource-Center}}</ref> A 2015 article in the ''Journal of Law and Education'' suggests that restrictions such as OHSAA's bylaw, as affirmed by the Sixth Circuit, should be revisited in light of the increasing importance of school athletics in future career prospects.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Third and Goal: High School Athletic Association Restrictions and the Privileges and Immunities Clause|first=Rachel|last=Dalton|work=Journal of Law & Education|publisher=[[University of South Carolina School of Law]]|volume=44|issue=4|date=Fall 2015|issn=0275-6072|url=https://www.questia.com/library/journal/1P3-3887369431/third-and-goal-high-school-athletic-association-restrictions}}</ref>
Despite the prohibition on out-of-state students, OHSAA's public member schools continued to complain that private schools and public open enrollment schools enjoyed an unfair advantage over public schools by drawing students from a broader geographic area than conventional school district boundaries. In May 2014, a majority of member school principals rejected a plan to hold separate district, regional, and state championships for public schools and private schools, similar to the proposal that failed in 1978. Instead, they voted to institute a "competitive balance" plan that took effect for six major sports during the 2017–18 school year.<ref>{{cite news|title=OHSAA announces plan to implement competitive balance in 2017-2018 school year|first=Michael|last=Beaven|work=[[Akron Beacon Journal]]|publisher=GateHouse Media|date=January 28, 2016|accessdate=May 20, 2018|url=https://www.ohio.com/akron/sports/ohsaa-announces-plan-to-implement-competitive-balance-in-2017-2018-school-year}}</ref>

The Royal Navy Rugby Union did not form until the 1907/08 season.http://navyrugby.co.uk'' | header2 = Other information | label3 = Current sponsor | data3 = [[Babcock International]] }} | trophy = The Babcock Trophy | broadcasters = | stadiums = [[Twickenham Stadium]] | map_location = | map_label1 = | map_label1_position = | latd1 = | latm1 = | lats1 = | latNS1 = | longd1 = | longm1 = | longs1 = | longEW1 = }} The '''Army Navy Match''' is the annual rugby union match played between the senior XV teams of the [[Royal Navy]] and [[British Army]]. It marks the culmination of the annual Inter-Services Competition. Although a match was played between the [[Officer (armed forces)|officers]] of the [[British Army]] and the officers of the [[Royal Navy]] at [[The Oval]], London on 13 February 1878, it was not until 1907 that the Army Navy Match became an annual fixture. For the first fixture the match Secretary was Surg Lt George Levick RN. From 1909 it was jointly administered by the newly formed [[Royal Navy Rugby Union]] (RNRU – 1907) The Army and Navy Gazette 16 Nov 1907 and the [[Army Rugby Union]] (ARU – 1906). Since then it has been played every season, with the exception of during the world wars (1914–19 and 1940–45) when the matches were suspended. ==Brief Background== Traditionally the Army Navy match has been played in the second half of the domestic season but in season 1907/1908 it was played in December and due to this anomaly the calendar year 1908 did not see an Army Navy match played yet they played each other twice in 1907.http://www.navyrugby.co.uk The 2016 Army Navy was the 99th in the series and the match saw another new record crowd of 81323 watch the Army Navy match which was one of the most compelling ever. The Navy took the lead 7–0 (Dave Fairbrother) on 20 minutes before the Army scored three tries (Semesa Rokoduguni 2, Owain Davies) before half time to lead 19–7 at the beak. A further try for the Army (James Farrell) early in the second period saw them extend their lead to 26-7 with half an hour of the match remaining. The Royal Navy staged the most remarkable of comebacks with tries from Gareth Rees and Rhys Dymmock-WIlliams either side of a penalty try to level the scores at 26-26 with 9 minutes remaining. An Owain Davies penalty with 2 minutes to go seemed to seal the win for the Army before Royal Navy fullback landed a 45m penalty of his own to again tie the game 29–29 with less than a minute to go. The draw meant that the Army Navy Trophy was shared but he Royal Navy were Inter Service Champions having beaten the RAF 9–8 at USSG Portsmouth. The RAF had beaten the Army 13–12 at RAF Halton in the opening round of the Inter Services. Royal Navy Number 8 completed a remarkable game which included a try, a yellow card and being named Man of the Match.http://navyrugby.co.uk The 2017 Army Navy match was unable to live up to the onfield excitement from the year before. However the 100th match saw another record crowd (81577), the attendance of Prince Harry as Patron of the Match Chairty, Invictus Games Foundation, and an Army win 29-20.http://www.navyrugby.co.uk The 101st Army Navy Match was played at Twickenham on 5 May 2018 with the Army winning 22-14. The match was notable in that the Navy had one man sent off in the first ten minutes of the game and the Army took advantage of their wing overlap to good effect. Army Corporal Matthew Dawson was awarded the Babcock Man of the Match.http://www.armynavymatch.org == The First Army Navy game 1878 == The first Army vs Navy game was held on 13 February 1878. A contemporary newspaper '''''The Broad Arrow''''' gave the following account of the match:
''A fine exhibition of football delighted the somewhat small number of spectators. Bush scored the first try for the Navy from a scrummage near the line. The goal was kicked by Orford. A band of naval spectators who had taken up their position beneath a white ensign mounted on the roof of a drag greeted this score with great cheering. The greasy state of the ground was not favourable for any great display of running. Encouraged by a cry from their supporters 'Come on Navy, Force the Passage of the Straights' the Navy mounted great pressure and scored a touch down. In the second half the Navy scored a second try. Wrench of the Army took advantage of some bad passing by the Navy and scored the Army try: The goal was kicked but this ended the scoring and the Navy deservedly won the first match between the Services.''
The full version of the report from the Broad Arrow seems to suggest that the correct quote of 'Force the Passage of the Straits' was used.http://navyrugby.co.uk/history-of-the-union/historical-events/1878-the-first-first-match/{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The Army selectors made a generous contribution towards the Navy victory by selecting a Royal Artillery officer, R Bannatyne, as Team Captain. He was serving overseas at the time and received no notification of his selection. As a result, he was absent for the game. The situation was further confounded by the fact that another Army player arrived late and missed a good part of the match. Walters |} {{Clear}} == The First "Official" Army Navy game 1907 == The Army Rugby Union was formed in 1906 whilst the exact date of formation of the Royal Navy Rugby Union is shrouded in doubt but is likely to have been towards the end of 1907, after the 1st official Army v Navy Match. February 1907 was when the first match organised by the two Services in a formal manner was played, with Surg Lt George Levick RN acting as the Match Secretary. The match was held at the Queen's Club, West Kensington and was won by the Officers of the Royal Navy 15-14.http://navyrugby.co.uk/history-of-the-union/historical-events/1907-the-second-first-match/{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} The match was played at Queen's Club until 1914. After the First World War the first match was hosted by Twickenham in 1920 and the game has been played there ever since.http://navyrugby.co.uk/senior-xv/senior-xv-inter-service-results/senior-xv-v-army/{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Team colours == Navy - Navy blue shorts, socks and shirt. Army - White shorts, red shirt and socks. In the first match of 1878 the Army played in white. The Navy have always played in blue jerseys though in 1955 their shorts were white.http://navyrugby.co.uk == Anniversary Army Navy Matches == The first eight matches were played at Queen's Club. Currently the 101 matches have resulted in 62 Army wins, 35 Navy wins and 4 draws which includes the thrilling 29-29 draw in 2016. The Royal Navy won the first match in 1907 but the Army have won the other anniversary matches. On 7 March 1936 the Army won the 25th match 12-3, in 1967 they won the 50th match 6-3, in 1992 they won the 75th match 16-9 and in 2017 they won the 100th match 29-20http://navyrugby.co.uk/senior-xv/senior-xv-inter-service-results/senior-xv-v-army/{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} == Match Results == === Pre Inter-Services Championship and Pre ArmyRugby Union / Roya Navy Rugby Union - Army Navy Matches (1878–1906) === {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" width="50%" !width="5%"| Year !width="5%"| Venue !width="5%"| Winner !width="5%"| Points !width="5%"| Loser !width="5%"| Points |- !1878 !Queen's Club |style="background: white; color: navy; text-align:center;" | Royal Navy |style="background: white; color: navy; text-align:center;" | 14 |- !1915-1919 |colspan="4" style="background: black; color: white; text-align:center;"| No matches played due to First World War{{cite web|url=http://www.armyrugbyunion.org.uk/about-the-aru/history-of-the-aru/army-navy-matches-1878-1914 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120303162537/http://www.armyrugbyunion.org.uk/about-the-aru/history-of-the-aru/army-navy-matches-1878-1914 |archivedate=2012-03-03 |df= }} |} * The first match that was an official Army Navy Match was in 1907 after the Army Rugby Union had formed in 1906 and with the Royal Navy moving towards formation. The match Secretary was Surg Lt George Levick and there was a charge for entry. The matches in 1878, 1880, 1905 and 1906 do not count towards the official record of matches between the two sides with February 1907 being the first and the 29 April 2017 the 100th match.{{Cite web |url=http://navyrugby.co.uk/royal-navy-rugby-union/history-of-the-union/historical-events/1907-the-second-first-match/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-05-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160602050635/http://navyrugby.co.uk/royal-navy-rugby-union/history-of-the-union/historical-events/1907-the-second-first-match/ |archive-date=2016-06-02 |dead-url=yes |df= }} === Inter-Services Championship (1920 to present day) === In 1920 a Tri-Service competition was created to include the newly formed Royal Air Force (RAF). However, the great rivalry between the Army and Navy has continued and their match, now held at the home of the English Rugby Football Union (Twickenham Stadium), remains the highlight of the annual inter-services rugby competition.http://www.raf.mod.uk/rafrugbyunion/interservices/sstats.cfm{{cite web|url=http://www.aru.org.uk/aru-history-interservice.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2008-11-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081224192028/http://www.aru.org.uk/aru-history-interservice.htm |archivedate=2008-12-24 |df= }} {| class="wikitable" align="center" style="width: 35em; font-size: 95%;" |- | colspan="3" style="text-align: center; font-size: 110%;" | '''Inter-Services Championship''' |- |valign="top"|'''Teams:''' |colspan="2"|[[Army Rugby Union]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Bethpage Ballpark | image = [[File:Bethpage Ballpark.png]]
[[Image:BethpageBallparkBirdsEye.jpg|300px]] | location = 3 Court House Drive
[[Central Islip, New York|Central Islip, NY]] 11722 | broke_ground = April, 1999 | opened = May 14, 2000 | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = Long Island Ducks | surface = grass | | construction_cost = | architect = Beatty Harvey Associates
HNTB Sports Architecture | former_names = EAB Park (2000–2001),
Citibank Park (2001-2010),
Suffolk County Sports Park (2010) | tenants = [[Long Island Ducks]] ([[Atlantic League of Professional Baseball|ALPB]]) (2000–present)
[[Long Island Lizards]] ([[Major League Lacrosse|MLL]]) (2001) | seating_capacity = 6,002 | dimensions = Left Field: {{convert|325|ft|m}} Center Field: {{convert|400|ft|m}} Right Field: {{convert|325|ft|m}} }} '''Bethpage Ballpark''' is a 6,002-seat [[baseball park]] in [[Central Islip, New York]] that serves as the home of the [[Long Island Ducks]], an independent minor league baseball team that is a member of the [[Atlantic League of Professional Baseball]]. Its first regular season game took place on May 14, 2000, when the Ducks played host to the [[Aberdeen Arsenal]]. The game was the first in the history of both franchises, as they both entered the Atlantic League at the same time. Bethpage Ballpark hosted the 2002 and 2010 Atlantic League All-Star Games. ==Naming rights== On July 17, 2001, [[Citigroup]] acquired European American Bank (EAB) for $1.6 billion and $350 million in preferred stock. The acquisition resulted in a name change from EAB Park to Citibank Park.[http://www.citi.com/citigroup/corporate/history/eab.htm Citigroup acquires EAB] However, Citigroup ended its corporate sponsorship in the spring of 2010 and the ballpark was given the temporary name "Suffolk County Sports Park" for the 2010 season.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsday.com/sports/baseball/citibank-ends-sponsorship-of-li-ducks-stadium-1.1731759|title=Citibank ends sponsorship of LI Ducks' stadium |last=Baumbach|first=Jim|date=January 29, 2010|newspaper=Newsday|accessdate=May 4, 2012}} On December 15, 2010, [[Suffolk County, New York|Suffolk County]] officials agreed to a $2.1 million deal with [[Bethpage Federal Credit Union]] to name the stadium "Bethpage Ballpark" until the 2020 season.{{cite news|url=http://www.newsday.com/long-island/towns/long-island-now-1.1732330/a-new-name-for-ducks-ballpark-1.2543566|title=A new name for Ducks' ballpark |last=Sullivan|first=Joseph|date=December 15, 2010|newspaper=Newsday|accessdate=May 4, 2012}} ==Ballpark attractions== {{Advert|section|date=October 2012}} Concessions at Bethpage Ballpark include mainly traditional ballpark fare, located at the [[Hebrew National]] Picnic Area. Beer connoisseurs can visit the Smokin' Als Party Deck for their choice beverage. In addition to Bethpage Ballpark's 6,002 chairback seats in the general seating area, it includes the Luxury Suites and the club level suites available for business or pleasure.[http://www.liducks.com/ballpark/seating/ Bethpage Ballpark seating diagram] There are also attractions for the kids, with an inflatable jump house down the 3rd base concourse, and an inflatable fast pitch tent down the 1st base concourse. The mascot, QuackerJack, also provides in-game entertainment. There are many games and contests fans take part in between innings.{{citation needed|date=October 2012}} ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061017203033/http://www.liducks.com/index.cfm?fuseaction=citibankPark Bethpage Ballpark] * [http://www.ballparkreviews.com/li/li.htm Ballpark Reviews - Bethpage Ballpark] * [http://www.digitalballparks.com/Atlantic/Citibank.html Digital Ballparks - Bethpage Ballpark] {{coord|40|45|54|N|73|11|32|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=title}} {{Long Island Ducks}} {{Atlantic League stadiums}} {{NewYorksportsvenues}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:Bethpage Ballpark}} [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Long Island]] [[Category:Islip (town), New York]] [[Category:Citigroup buildings]] [[Category:Baseball venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Atlantic League ballparks]] [[Category:Sports venues in Suffolk County, New York]] [[Category:Lacrosse venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:2000 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2000]]

Auditorium | image3 = File:Owner Mr Hamdan Al Maktoum.svg | alt3 = Royal blue, white epaulets, striped cap | caption3 = Haafhd }} {{Jockey colours footer}} The '''Champagne Stakes''' is a [[Conditions races|Group 2]] [[Flat racing|flat]] [[Horse racing|horse race]] in Great Britain open to two-year-old [[Colt (horse)|colts]] and [[gelding]]s. It is run at [[Doncaster Racecourse|Doncaster]] over a distance of 7 furlongs and 6 yards (1,414 metres), and it is scheduled to take place each year in September. ==History== The event was established in 1823, and it was originally open to horses of either gender. For a period it was contested over a mile, and it was shortened to 6 furlongs in 1870. It was extended to 7 furlongs in 1962, and restricted to male horses in 1988. The Champagne Stakes is held during Doncaster's four-day St. Leger Festival, and it is currently run on the final day, the same day as the [[St Leger Stakes]]. The leading horses from the race sometimes go on to compete in the following month's [[Dewhurst Stakes]]. ==Records== {{refbegin}} '''Leading [[jockey]] (9 wins):''' * [[William Scott (jockey)|Bill Scott]] – ''Swiss (1823), Memnon (1824), The Colonel (1827), Francesca (1831), Cotillon (1833), Jereed (1836), Don John (1837), Launcelot (1839), Attila (1841)'' '''Leading [[Horse trainer|trainer]] (10 wins):''' * [[John Scott (horseman)|John Scott]] – ''Swiss (1823), The Colonel (1827), Jereed (1836), Don John (1837), Launcelot (1839), Attila (1841), Vindex (1852), The Bonnie Morn (1854), Prelude (1858), The Marquis (1861)'' * [[Mathew Dawson]] – ''Zambezi (1864), Sunshine (1869), Camballo (1874), Farnese (1875), Lady Golightly (1876), Charibert (1878), Bal Gal (1880), Langwell (1884), Minting (1885), Ladas (1893)'' {{refend}} ==Winners since 1974== {| class = "sortable" | border="1" style="border-collapse: collapse; font-size:90%" |- bgcolor="#77dd77" align="center" ! [[File:DoubleDutchBA.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Children playing double Dutch in [[Buenos Aires]]]] '''Double Dutch''' is a game in which two long [[jump ropes]] turning in opposite directions are jumped by one or more players jumping simultaneously. It is believed to have originated among Dutch immigrants in New York City, and is now popular worldwide.<ref name="wsj">{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB119448972267686072|title=Bested by Japan, A Jump-Rope Team Plots a Comeback|date=9 November 2007|author=Jamin Brophy-Warren|work=WSJ|accessdate=31 December 2016}}</ref> While it had long been a popular street activity for African American girls in New York City, the modern sport of Double Dutch originated in the early 1970s with [[NYPD]] officers Ulysses Williams and David Walker, who formalized the rules for competition. The first official competition was held in 1974. In the early 1980s, Double Dutch was strongly associated with New York [[hip hop]] culture.<ref name=vice>Lauren Schwartzberg, [https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/nn974m/double-dutchs-forgotten-hip-hop-origins-456 Double Dutch's Forgotten Hip-Hop Origins], vice.com, April 1, 2015</ref>Competitions in double Dutch range from block parties to the world level. During the spring of 2009, double Dutch became a varsity sport in New York City public high schools.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/07/31/education/31double.html|title=Double Dutch Gets Status in the Schools|date=31 July 2008|author=Hu, Winnie|publisher=''New York Times''|accessdate=31 December 2016}}</ref>
==Technique== [[File:BLACK CHILDREN PLAY OUTSIDE THE IDA B. WELLS HOMES, ONE OF CHICAGO'S OLDEST HOUSING PROJECTS. THERE ARE 1,652... - NARA - 556160.jpg|thumb|Girls playing double Dutch outside The [[Ida B. Wells Homes]] in Chicago, 1973.]] [[File:US Navy 030303-N-9109V-006 Steel Beach picnic aboard USS Saipan.jpg|thumb|alt=Picture of US service personnel jumping double Dutch on the deck of an aircraft carrier|[[US navy|US sailors]] and [[us marines|marines]] participate in a double Dutch contest on the deck of the [[USS Saipan (LHA-2)|USS Saipan]] during a ship celebration.]] Playing double Dutch involves at least three people: one or more jumping, and two turning the ropes. A jumper usually performs tricks that may involve [[gymnastics]] or [[breakdance]], and may also incorporate fancy foot movements.
==Double Dutch in the media== The 1981 single "[[Double Dutch Bus]]" by Frankie Smith features African American girls playing this game in the video clip of the song.<ref>{{cite web|title=Frankie Smith - Double Dutch Bus (Official Music Video)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fK9hK82r-AM|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=16 January 2018|ref=ddbus}}</ref>
The 1983 single by Malcolm McLaren, "[[Double Dutch (song)|Double Dutch]]" features a number of New York City troupes. It is taken from his debut album Duck Rock.<ref>{{cite web|title=Malcolm Mclaren Presents Double Dutch|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FZ4jMSCBswY|website=YouTube|accessdate=16 January 2018|ref=mmdd}}</ref>
The 1991 single by American hip-hop duo [[DJ Jazzy Jeff & The Fresh Prince]], "[[Summertime (DJ Jazzy Jeff & The Fresh Prince song)|Summertime]]" mentions "girls playing Double Dutch". It is taken from their fourth studio album, ''[[Homebase (album)|Homebase]]''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Summertime DJ Jazzy Jeff & The Fresh Prince|url=https://genius.com/Dj-jazzy-jeff-and-the-fresh-prince-summertime-lyrics|website=Lyrics Genius|publisher=Genius Media Group|accessdate=16 January 2018|ref=summer}}</ref>
''Doubletime'', a documentary from Discovery Films, tells the story of the historic meet-up of rope skipping and double Dutch. The film follows two top teams; the Bouncing Bulldogs and the Double Dutch Forces, as they train to compete against each other for the very first time. The competition takes place at the [[Apollo Theater]] in Harlem.<ref>{{cite web|title=Doubletime (2007)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1006867/|website=IMDB|publisher=IMDB|accessdate=16 January 2018}}</ref>
In 2005, Elizabeth Verity, aka Double Dutch Girl, began jumping her way around the U.S. raising money for the United States military. Double Dutch Girl jumped rope in St. Louis, Chicago, Washington and several small towns throughout the Midwest. Ultimately, her goal is to jump rope in all 50 states.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ourmilitary.mil/Content.aspx?ID%3D26625554 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100410073206/http://www.ourmilitary.mil/Content.aspx?ID=26625554 |archivedate=2010-04-10 |df= }}</ref>
The 2007 [[Disney Channel]] original movie ''[[Jump In!]]'' features double Dutch as the central element of its plot. ''Jump In!'' features the [[Dutch Dragons]], based on a real double Dutch team from 1997 in [[Harlem]]. ''Jump!'',<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.jumpmovie.com/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2009-09-02 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090821230305/http://www.jumpmovie.com/ |archive-date=2009-08-21 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> an award-winning documentary following five teams from around the United States who push their physical and psychological limits in pursuit of winning the World Rope Skipping Championship, also premiered at the [[Los Angeles Film Festival]] in 2007
In 2010, Saltare was on [[America's Best Dance Crew (season 5)|season 5 of America's Best Dance Crew]] and the group featured single rope and double Dutch in their dance routines.<ref name="USA Jump Rope">{{cite web|title=Saltare|url=http://www.usajrf.org/saltare.asp|publisher=USA Jump Rope|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120628070315/http://www.usajrf.org/saltare.asp|archivedate=2012-06-28|df=}}</ref><ref name="Cary Citizen">{{cite news|last=Goodtree|first=Hal|title=Morrisville's Saltare on America's Best Dance Crew|url=http://carycitizen.com/2010/02/07/morrisvilles-saltare-on-americas-best-dance-crew/|newspaper=carycitizen.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121019142537/http://carycitizen.com/2010/02/07/morrisvilles-saltare-on-americas-best-dance-crew/|archivedate=2012-10-19|df=}}</ref>
A 2010 PBS documentary, ''[[New York Street Games (film)|New York Street Games]]'', includes Whoopi Goldberg describing double Dutch.<ref>{{cite video |author1 = [[Hector Elizondo]] (Narrator) |author2 = Matt Levy (Director) |accessdate = 14 Nov 2011 |url = http://www.newyorkstreetgames.com/home.html |title = New York Street Games |medium = Motion picture |location = New York City |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20111113235948/http://www.newyorkstreetgames.com/home.html |archive-date = 2011-11-13 |dead-url = yes |df = }}</ref>
On January 15, 2007, in honor of [[Martin Luther King, Jr. Day]], the Google homepage featured a double Dutch logo with black children playing with white children, emblematic of the realization of [[Martin Luther King, Jr]]'s "[[I Have A Dream]]" speech in 1963.<ref>[http://www.google.com/logos/mlk07.gif Google MLK Day logo]</ref>
The game is featured in the Wee Sing production "Grandpa's Magical Toys".<ref>{{cite web|title=Wee Sing Grandpa's Magical Toys|url=http://weesing.com/DVDs/Wee-Sing-Grandpas-Magical-Toys|website=Wee Sing|publisher=Penguin Group|accessdate=16 January 2018|ref=ws}}</ref>
The music video to the 2010 track by [[DJ Fresh]], ''Gold Dust'', centres on double Dutch skipping.<ref>{{cite web|title=DJ Fresh - 'Gold Dust' (Official Video)|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RNuUgbUzM8U|website=YouTube|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=16 January 2018|ref=ytfresh}}</ref>
In the music video of Yves Larock hit 2007 track "Rise Up", double Dutch is the theme used.<ref>{{cite web|title=Yves LaRock - Rise Up|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zoMYU_nOGNg|website=YouTube|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=16 January 2018|ref=yyt}}</ref>
In his dual title role of the 2011 movie ''[[Jack and Jill (2011 film)|Jack & Jill]]'', [[Adam Sandler]] gives a demonstration of double Dutch jump rope on board the cruise liner.<ref>{{cite web|title=Clip from Jack and Jill movie|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fGe3VBx8g9Y|website=YouTube|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=16 January 2018|ref=jj}}</ref>
There is a double Dutch jump roping competition in the 2015 film ''[[War Room (film)|War Room]]''.<ref>[http://www.catholicworldreport.com/Blog/4148/a_spiritual_battle_in_the_war_room.aspx A Spiritual Battle in the War Room]</ref>
== Competitive Double Dutch == The National Double Dutch League holds yearly camps and a Holiday Classic, in which teams from all over the world compete. Double Dutch is also an integral part of USA Jump Rope Tournaments as well as the AAU Junior Olympic Games and [http://worldjumprope.org/# the World Jump Rope Federation]'s worldwide annual competitions.
The World Jump Rope Championships were held in July, 2012, at George Washington University, in Washington D.C.<ref name="Bainbridge Review">{{cite web|last=Kelly|first=Brian|title=Bainbridge jumpers win gold medals at world championship|url=http://www.bainbridgereview.com/sports/164910036.html|publisher=bainbridgereview.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Owens|first=Dave|title=World Jump Rope Championships Unlike Jumping Rope In Your Backyard|url=http://www.wusa9.com/news/article/157291/158/www.kissestocancer.com|publisher=WUSA 9}}</ref>
Double Dutch competitions are categorized as compulsory, freestyle, and speed rope. [[File:Legends Of National Double League gather at Lincoln Center.jpg|thumb|Legends Of National Double League gather at Lincoln Center]]
== Double Dutch in France == Double Dutch is associated with the early French [[hip-hop]] scene. It was introduced in late 1982 when the World Champion Fantastic Four double dutch team came to France along with the NYC Rap Tour. Groups such as the Dutch Force System, Ladie's Night, and Crétil were some of the better-known double Dutch groups. Double Dutch was seen as ''"the symbol of a strong and affirmed femininity in hip-hop" ''.<ref>{{cite book |last=Piolet |first=Vincent |date=June 2015 |title=Regarde ta jeunesse dans les yeux: naissance du hip-hop française, 1980-1990 |location=France|publisher=Horizon |page=90 |isbn=9782360541676|language=fr}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== * Veronica Chambers, ''Double Dutch'', {{ISBN|978-0-7868-0512-9}}, Jump At The Sun; 1 edition (October 14, 2002) * Kyra D. Gaunt, ''The Games Black Girls Play: Learning the Ropes from Double-Dutch to Hip-hop'', {{ISBN|0-8147-3120-1}}, Published 2006 NYU Press
== External links == * [http://www.doubletimefilm.com/ Doubletime, Discovery Channel (documentary)] * [http://www.nationaldoubledutchleague.com/ National Double Dutch League] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070225193529/http://www.usajrf.org/ USA Jump Rope website] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070515042219/http://www.brsa.org.uk/ British Rope Skipping Association]

{{Infobox stadium| stadium_name=Estádio Municipal 20 de Janeiro| image=| image_size= |pushpin_map = Cape Verde | map_size = 350px | pushpin_map_size = 350px | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = | pushpin_relief = | pushpin_label = | pushpin_label_position = |coordinates = {{Coord|15.137|-23.2052}}| location=[[Cidade do Maio]] on [[Maio, Cape Verde|Maio Island]], Cape Verde| opened=2008| owner=[[Maio Regional Football Association]]| tenants=''[[Académica da Calheta]]''
''[[Barreirense (Cape Verde)|Barreirense]]''
[[Académico 83]]
[[Onze Unidos]]| cost=| seating_capacity=1,000 }} '''Estádio Municipal 20 de Janeiro''' is a multi-use [[stadium]] in [[Maio, Cape Verde|Maio]], [[Cape Verde]]. Its location is east of the town center of [[Cidade do Maio]] about 300 meters nearly south of the Maio-[[Figueira da Horta]] Road (EN3-MA01), the Maio Circular Route and is in the residential sector. It stadium is named after a holiday named Heroes Day It is currently used mostly for [[football (soccer)|football]] matches and is the home stadium of [[Académico 83]] and [[Onze Unidos]]. Every other clubs from the island based outside Cidade do Maio including [[Académica da Calheta]] and [[Barreirense (Cape Verde)|Barreirense]] plays at the stadium. The stadium is operated by the [[Maio Regional Football Association]] (ARFM). The stadium holds 1.000 people (some sources says 4,000) {{cite web|title=Stadiums in Cape Verde|url=http://www.worldstadiums.com/africa/countries/cape_verde.shtml|work=World Stadiums|publisher=WorldStadiums.Com|accessdate=21 December 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111230040241/http://www.worldstadiums.com/africa/countries/cape_verde.shtml|archivedate=30 December 2011|df=}}and size is 100x64 m and its grass is artificial. Every football (soccer) championships of the [[Maio Island League]] along with the [[Maio Cup]], the [[Maio Super Cup]] and the [[Maio Opening Tournament]] are played at the stadium. Also track and field at the regional level (Boa Vista-Maio) are played. ==Early stadium== The previous stadium '''Estádio Municipal do Maio''' was opened around the 1970s. The regional championships were first held until 1991. The stadium closed down in 2008 and moved it 300 meters to the south. Industrial and business buildings popped up in the same time in that area. Today the old stadium is abandoned and has disused seats there. A few trees have grown on the abandoned field. ==Modern stadium== Construction started in the mid 2000s. The stadium was first opened in, 2008. The first regional cup, super cup and opening tournament competitions took place in 2011. Artificial grass has recently been added.{{cite web|url=http://inforpress.publ.cv/desporto/137680-maio-dirigentes-desportivos-aguardam-com-expectativas-a-conclusao-da-segunda-fase-do-estadio-municipal|title=Maio: Dirigentes desportivos aguardam "com expectativas" a conclusão da segunda fase do estádio municipal|publisher=[[Inforpress]]|language=pt|date=14 January 2017|accessdate=16 January 2017}} ==See also== *[[List of football stadiums in Cape Verde]] *[[Maio Island League]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Cape Verdean Football Championships venues}} {{Académico 83 do Porto Inglês}} {{coord|15|08|13|N|23|12|19|E|source:wikidata-and-enwiki-cat-tree_region:CV|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:20 Janeiro Municipal Estadio}} [[Category:Football venues in Cape Verde]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2008]] [[Category:Sport in Maio, Cape Verde]] [[Category:Académico 83]] [[Category:Académica da Calheta do Maio]] {{CapeVerde-sports-venue-stub}}

[[Image:filGoal.png|right|thumb]]
''' FilGoal.com ''' (In the Goal) is an [[Egypt]]ian [[sports]] website, owned and managed by [[Sarmady]] (a subsidiary of [[Vodafone Egypt]]),<ref name="voda1">(27 August 2009). [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=aGZucu8scLH4 Yahoo’s Purchase of Maktoob May Boost Arab Online Advertising], ''[[Bloomberg L.P.]]'', Retrieved December 16, 2010 ("Vodafone Egypt last year purchased Sarmady, a Cairo-based provider of digital content... Filgoal.com, Sarmady’s sports Web site.")</ref> FilGoal's main scope is [[association football|football]] news. It covers the [[Egyptian Premier League|Egyptian]], [[Saudi Professional League|Saudi]] and [[UEFA|European leagues]], as well as the [[UEFA Champions League]], [[Africa Cup of Nations]], the [[FIFA World Cup]] and other international competitions. It provides over 20 news pieces a day beside opinion pieces and interviews with both players and [[coach (sport)|coaches]]. With services ranging from streaming [[Internet radio|web radio]] commentary and analysis, visitors' own analysis section, match previews and [[review]]s.
FilGoal.com is published in [[Arabic]] and [[English language|English]].
The 1st version of FilGoal logo was created in 2001 by Mostafa Farahat.<ref name="mosti">{{Cite web|url=http://www.behance.net/mosti|title=Behance|website=www.behance.net|access-date=2018-08-13}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
'''Gladiator chess''' is a [[chess]] [[tournament]] style. It was introduced in the 2006 [[Danish Chess Championship]]s.
In gladiator chess no draws are accepted. In case the game ends in a draw, it is played again with reversed colors and shorter time limits. Specifically the first game is played so that each player has 100 minutes for 40 moves and then 30 minutes, always adding 30 seconds per move. In case of a draw, the time settings are changed to 25 minutes, adding 10 seconds per move. In case of another draw, the players will continue to play [[blitz chess]], 10 minutes per player, adding 5 seconds per move.
==External links== *[http://www.chesscenter.com/twic/twic596.html#5 The Week in Chess 596 10 April 2006 by Mark Crowther: 5) Danish Championship] *[http://www.chessninja.com/cgi-bin/mt-comments.cgi?entry_id=857 The Daily Dirt Chess Blog: Comment on National Championship Beat]
{{chess-tournament-stub}} [[Category:Chess tournament systems]] [[Category:2006 in chess]]

{{Infobox football biography
|name = Jonathan Richard |fullname= Jonathan Jordan Richard |birth_date= 21 June 1991 |birth_place= [[Amsterdam]] |position= [[Midfielder|Attacking midfielder]] |youthyears1= -2010 |youthclubs1= [[AFC Amsterdam]]<ref name="amsterdam"/> |years1= 2010-2011 |clubs1= [[AFC Amsterdam]] |caps1 = 3 |goals1= 0 |years2= 2011-2014 |clubs2= [[OFC Oostzaan]] |years3= 2014- |clubs3= [[AFC Amsterdam]] |nationalyears1= 2015 |nationalteam1= [[Curacao national football team|Curacao]] |nationalcaps1= 2+ |nationalgoals1= 0 }}
'''Jonathan Richard''' (born 21 June 1991 in the [[Netherlands]]) is a [[Curacao]] footballer who currently plays for [[AFC Amsterdam]] as of 2014.
==Career==
===AFC===
Returning to [[AFC Amsterdam]] in 2014,<ref name="amsterdam">{{cite web|url=https://www.hetamsterdamschevoetbal.nl/jonathan-richard-ofc-keert-terug-op-oude-nest-bij-afc/|title=Jonathan Richard (OFC) keert terug op ‘oude nest’ bij AFC - Het Amsterdamsche Voetbal|website=www.hetamsterdamschevoetbal.nl}}</ref> Richard was praised by their coach [[Willem Leushuis]] for his effervescent and sociable personality, netting two goals in two games in a row as well.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afc.nl/nieuws?c=2&id=3098|title=AFC - Jonathan Richard 'In 'de Schijnwerper'|website=www.afc.nl}}</ref>
===International===
Making his first outing for the [[Curacao national football team|Curacao national team]] in a 2015 unofficial friendly fronting [[Suriname national football team|Suriname]], Richard was selected for the Curacao squad in their two 2018 World Cup qualifiers facing [[Cuba national football team|Cuba]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhnieuws.nl/nieuws/164835/Jonathan-Richard-in-definitieve-selectie-Curacao|title=Jonathan Richard in definitieve selectie Curaçao|publisher=}}</ref>
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://us.soccerway.com/players/jonathan-richard/158955/ at Soccerway] * [http://www.national-football-teams.com/player/59417/Jonathan_Richard.html at National-Football-Teams]

{{Curaçao-footy-bio-stub}}

It is governed by the [[Macedonian Tennis Federation]]. They have not competed since [[2001 Fed Cup|2001]]. ==History== Macedonia competed in its first Fed Cup in [[1995 Fed Cup|1995]]. Their best result was earning promotion to Group I in [[2000 Fed Cup|2000]].
