revision.text:
[[File:Shea Rowing Center.jpg|300px|thumb|right|The C. Bernard Shea Rowing Center at [[Princeton University]]]]
The '''C. Bernard Shea Rowing Center''' is the boathouse for the [[Princeton University]] rowing programs. Located on [[Lake Carnegie]] in [[Princeton, New Jersey]], the center consists of the Class of 1887 Boathouse and the Richard Ottesen Prentke ‘67 Training Center. The Shea Center was dedicated on October 7, 2000.
== History ==
Rowing began at Princeton in 1870 with a half-dozen undergraduates and two boats, which the students taught themselves to row on the [[Delaware and Raritan Canal]].<ref>Leitch, Alexander (1978). ''A Princeton Companion''. Princeton University Press.</ref> By 1874, the Princeton Boating Club had been formed and had obtained a wood-framed boathouse on the canal. But by 1884, the canal had become so busy with steam-powered boat traffic that rowing was forced to cease. Early in the 20th century, former coxswain Howard Russell Butler convinced [[Andrew Carnegie]] to create a lake at Princeton. When some lakeside property owners demanded to sell their entire farms, Carnegie balked at providing full financing, Butler and a group of eleven other alumni generously stepped in and purchased over a hundred acres of land, 89 of which were then given to the University. Other alumni gave hundreds of acres of land to the University at the same time. The lake was finally completed in 1906.<ref>Rivinus, Willis (2005). ''Rowing at Princeton''. Princeton University Rowing Association.</ref>
With a fine body of water on which to compete, rowing began again in 1911. In 1913, the Class of 1887 Boathouse was donated to the University on the occasion of the 25th reunion of the Class; they had been the last class to row on the Canal. The {{convert|22000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} structure initially accommodated only 3 full eights of heavyweight oarsmen.
As Princeton added new rowing programs, the building housed heavyweight, lightweight, women’s and lightweight women’s crew programs. There were a number of piecemeal modifications over the years to accommodate the additional athletes, leaving a building that was maze-like and confusing. By 1997, the boathouse was serving more than 160 athletes on a daily basis, and was packed beyond overflowing. Additionally, the building was falling into disrepair. Indeed, a 1996 meeting of the Princeton University Rowing Association (PURA) was punctuated by a window falling out.<ref>Princeton Rowing Notes, winter 2000</ref> Subsequent to this meeting, PURA president Dick Prentke ‘67 initiated the effort to work with University to pursue a full-scale renovation and addition.
PURA turned to architect and former lightweight rower Jeff Peterson ’84 to explore initial concepts for the project. Peterson's firm at that time, Architectural Resources Cambridge, was eventually hired to design the project. After the project, Peterson started Peterson Architects, a firm that focuses primarily on boathouses.
PURA raised more than $8 million from over 1200 donors for the project, including a $4 million gift by Irene C. Shea in memory of her husband C. Bernard Shea ‘1916. Mr. Shea had been a student when the 1887 Boathouse opened and was an avid fan of rowing and all things Princeton.<ref>[https://www.princeton.edu/pr/pwb/00/1002/8.shtml "Dedication Set For Rowing Center"], ''Princeton Weekly Bulletin'', October 2, 2000. Retrieved on 2010-11-7.</ref>
Construction commenced in June 1999. Crews were able to partially occupy the 1887 Boathouse for boat storage in the spring of 2000. The project was completed in time for full occupancy in the fall of 2000.
An unusually heavy rainfall in April 2007 caused the water level in Lake Carnegie to rise several feet, flooding Shea Rowing Center and suspending activities for several days.<ref>Krauss, Sam. [http://www.dailyprincetonian.com/2007/04/17/18112/ "Storm Forces University to Curtail Operations"],''The Daily Princetonian'', April 17, 2007. Retrieved on 2010-11-7.</ref> After the flood, the University engaged Peterson Architects to repair the facility and to mitigate potential damage from future floods.
== Design ==
The C. Bernard Shea Rowing Center serves as a gateway to the Princeton Campus, the first visible buildings when approaching from the east. The center consists of the original Class of 1887 Boathouse (22,000 s.f.) and the Richard Ottesen Prentke Training Center (13,500 s.f.). To achieve architectural consistency, the newer Prentke Center reiterates the bay spacing, hipped roofs, and tripartite window configurations of the original building. The tower of the 1887 Boathouse is the center's entry and focal point. On its second floor, it features a double-height sky-lit space with mahogany flooring, benches and wainscoting. A gallery extending to the west features historical photographs, overlooks the lake and provides access to shower and locker facilities. The gallery arrives at a grand open-timbered club room with lounge seating, trophy cases, and video facilities. The Prentke Center includes two bays for small boats, and a moving-water rowing tank. In the tank, the broadly arched window evokes the arches of the Washington Street Bridge. The upper level contains three large workout spaces framed with heavy timber trusses. These rooms are finished with mahogany wainscot and athletic rubber flooring.<ref>Rivinus, Willis (2005). ''Rowing at Princeton''. Princeton University Rowing Association.</ref>
== Awards ==
The Shea Rowing Center has won a number of architectural design awards, including a 2005 Boston Society of Architects Honor Award for Design<ref>''Architecture Boston'', Jan/Feb 2006</ref> and a 2001 Facility of Merit Award from Athletic Business Magazine.<ref>''Athletic Business'', December 2001</ref> It was also recognized by Boathouse Finder as a building of outstanding “Architectural Achievement.”<ref>[http://www.bhfinder.com/boathouses/Page-8/ "Architectural Achievement Boathouses,"] Boathouse Finder. Retrieved on 11/15/2010.</ref>
== Notes == <!--- See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Footnotes on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist}}

{{Use Australian English|date=September 2018}} {{Infobox song | name = Sir Don | cover = Sir_Don_by_John_Williamson.jpg | caption = | artist = [[John Williamson (singer)|John Williamson]] | type = single | album = [[Pipe Dream (John Williamson album)|Pipe Dream]] | B-side = | studio = | released = {{Start date|1996|06}} | format = CD single | genre = Country | length = {{Duration|m=|s=}} | label = [[EMI Music]] | writer = John Williamson | producer = John Williamson | prev_title = Tropical Fever | prev_year = 1994 | next_title = Bush Telegraph | next_year = 1997 }} '''Sir Don''' is a song written and recorded by Australian country singer [[John Williamson (singer)|John Williamson]]. The song is a tribute to Australian cricketer, [[Donald Bradman]] and $1 from each sale went towards the [[Bradman Museum]]. The song was released in June 1996 as the lead single from Williamson's thirteenth studio album ''[[Pipe Dream (John Williamson album)|Pipe Dream]]'' and peaked at number 72 on the [[ARIA Charts]]. Following Bradman's death in February 2001, Williamson performed the track at Bradman's Memorial Service at [[St Peter's Cathedral, Adelaide]].{{cite web|url=http://johnwilliamson.com.au/photos/attachment/bradman_tb2/|title=2001 John performs his tribute at Sir Donald Bradman’s Memorial Service. |publisher=John Williamson|date=5 May 2014|accessdate=20 September 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/australia-culture-blog/2014/aug/15/our-don-review-adelaide-natalie-williams|title= Our Don review Donald Bradman's symphonic tribute hits for six|publisher=The Guardian|date= 15 August 2014|accessdate=20 September 2018}}{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/in_depth/2001/death_of_don_bradman/1241178.stm|title=Greats attend Bradman tribute|date=25 March 2001|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|accessdate=23 August 2018}} The original scraps of paper this song was written on have been framed and hang in the Bradman Museum at [[Bowral]].{{cite web|url=http://www.australianjazzagency.com.au/artist/78-artist-showcase/180-john-williamson.html|title=John Williamson |publisher=Australian Jazz Agency|accessdate=20 September 2018}} == Track listing == {{Track listing | total_length = | title1 = Sir Don | length1 = | title2 = My Oath to Australia | length2 = | title3 = Paint Me a Wheelbarrow | length3 = | title4 = Sydney 2000 | length4 = }} ==Weekly charts== {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! Chart (1996) ! Peak
position |- ! scope="row"| Australia ([[ARIA Charts|ARIA]]){{cite book|last=Ryan|first=Gavin|title=Australia's Music Charts 1988–2010|year=2011|publisher=Moonlight Publishing|location=Mt. Martha, VIC, Australia}} | 72 |- |} ==Release history== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- ! scope="col"| Region ! scope="col"| Date ! scope="col"| Format ! scope="col"| Edition(s) ! scope="col"| Label ! scope="col"| Catalogue |- | Australia | June 1996 | {{flat list| *[[Compact Cassette|Cassette]] *[[CD single]]}} | Standard | [[EMI Music]] | 8740883 |- |} == References == {{reflist}} {{John Williamson (singer)}} [[Category:John Williamson (singer) songs]] [[Category:Songs about sportspeople]] [[Category:Sporting songs]] [[Category:Cricket culture]] [[Category:Cultural depictions of Donald Bradman]] [[Category:1996 songs]] [[Category:1996 singles]]

revision.comment: moved [[Southampton Leisure Holdings PLC]] to [[Southampton Leisure Holdings]]: per [[WP:NCCORP]]
revision.text:
'''Southampton Leisure Holdings [[Public_Limited_Company|PLC]]''' was the parent company of [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton Football Club Ltd]] and was listed on the [[Alternative Investment Market]] of the [[London Stock Exchange]]. The company was placed into administration on 2 April 2009.
== Subsidiaries ==
The wholly owned subsidiary companies of Southampton Leisure Holdings PLC were:
* Southampton Football Club Ltd * St. Mary's Stadium Ltd * St. Mary's SPV Ltd * Southampton Insurance Services Ltd * Southampton Mortgage & Financial Centre Ltd * Saints Supporters Club Ltd * Southampton Swaylife Ltd * Secure Retirement Ltd * Dell Estates Ltd * St Michael's Street Homes (No. 1) Ltd * Stadium 2000 Ltd * Felix Broadcasting Ltd * South City FM Ltd * Forest FM Ltd
== History == On 30 June 2006, [[Rupert Lowe]] resigned as Chairman of Southampton Leisure Holdings, along with other directors Andrew Cowen, Guy Askham, Mike Richards and David Windsor-Clive.
On 26 February 2007, [[Michael Wilde]] offered his resignation as a Director effective from 28 February 2007 as a result of his failure to bring in new investment. The resignation was accepted by the board as being in the best interests of the company.<ref>[http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/news/?page_id=8222 SAINTSFC.CO.UK: / News / Archive / Club Statement]</ref>
On 27 April 2007, it was rumoured that [[Paul Allen]], the [[United States|American]] entrepreneur who formed [[Microsoft]] with [[Bill Gates]], may launch a takeover bid for [[Southampton F.C.|the club]]. An apparent close source said "he believes there is long term investment value in UK [[Soccer]]. Southampton is a sleeping giant, a family-supported club with traditional values, and we see the value in taking the brand global."<ref name="Saints confirm takeover bid received">{{cite news| title = Saints confirm takeover bid received| url = http://www.dailyecho.co.uk/display.var.1359684.0.saints_confirm_takeover_bid_received.php| publisher = Daily Echo| date = 27 April 2007| accessdate = 27 April 2007}}</ref>
== Administration == Shares in the Company were suspended from trading on 1 April 2009, when the Company announced that it was in negotiations to secure additional financing to ensure that it was able to continue trading.
On 2 April 2009, Southampton Leisure Holdings declared [[Administration (law)|administration]] after it failed to gain investment to last for the next financial year. Administrators Mark Fry and David Hudson, partners of [[Begbies Traynor]], took over control of the parent company and all assets until a new owner could be found. <ref name="Southampton Fc in Admistration">{{cite news| title = Southampton FC owner falls into administration| url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/football_league/article6018444.ece| publisher = The Times| accessdate = 24 October 2009 | location=London | date=2 April 2009 | first1=Catherine | last1=Boyle | first2=Helen | last2=Power | first3=Gary | last3=Jacob}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| title = Mark Fry and David Hudson of Begbies Traynor appointed as joint administrators to Southampton Leisure Holdings plc| url =http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/articles/article.php?page_id=11581 | publisher = [[Southampton F.C.]] | date = 2 April 2009| accessdate = 2 April 2009}}</ref>
On 27 July 2009, DMWSL 613 Limited, a company controlled by [[Markus Liebherr]] brought [[Southampton Football Club]] and all its assets form the administrator.<ref>{{cite news| title = administrator Confirms SFC Sold!| url = http://www.saintsfc.co.uk/page/NewsDetail/0,,10280~1716797,00.html| publisher = Southampton FC| accessdate = 24 October 2009}}</ref> On 2 October, the listing of the shares for Southampton Leisure Holdings was cancelled.<ref>{{cite news| title = Cancellation - Southampton Leisure Holdings plc (AIM)| url = http://www.advfn.com/p.php?pid=nmona&cb=1256388765&article=39724647&symbol=L^SOO| accessdate = 24 October 2009}}</ref>
The company was placed in Creditors' Voluntary Liquidation on 22 February 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wck2.companieshouse.gov.uk/f05e6f99c6d2f85f842a30227a94a2f3/insolvency|title=Insolvency History|date=25 February 2010|publisher=[[Companies House]]|accessdate=2 April 2010}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Southampton F.C.|Southampton Leisure Holdings plc]] [[Category:Publicly traded sports companies]]

A '''system quarterback''' is an [[American football]] [[quarterback]] who flourishes under a particular offensive [[play calling system|system]], specifically one that focuses on [[forward pass|passing]]. The term is often seen as a pejorative, for it implicitly downplays a quarterback's talent or skill by implying that a successful offense is due to a particular scheme or that a quarterback is successful due to his employment under specific circumstances. A system quarterback is usually perceived as having their statistics inflated by a particular strategy. Offensive schemes that tend to feature so-called system quarterbacks are the "[[Run & Shoot|run and shoot]]", [[spread offense|spread]], and, less frequently, [[option offense|spread option]] offenses.<ref name="espn">[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/columns/story?columnist=maisel_ivan&id=3145177 Heisman candidates could make history -- and change minds], ESPN, December 7, 2007.</ref><ref name="dallas">[http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/football/nfl/gosselin/position/stories/041005dnspodraftseriesqb.a981c.html Quarterback: 'System' label a burden come draft time], ''Dallas Morning News'', April 22, 2005.</ref>
==Origin== Russ Lande of ''[[Sporting News]]'' traced the term's etymology, or at least currency, to the early 1990s, when two University of Houston quarterbacks failed to carry college success into their professional careers.<ref name="tsn"/> First, [[Andre Ware]], in head coach [[Jack Pardee]] and offensive coordinator [[John Jenkins (American football coach)|John Jenkins]]'s run and shoot offense, had a record-setting 1989 season that culminated in a [[Heisman Trophy]]. He was the seventh overall pick in the [[1990 NFL Draft]], but did not have success in either the [[National Football League]] or the [[Canadian Football League]].<ref>[http://espn.go.com/page2/s/list/heisman/flops.html The List: Biggest Heisman Flops], ESPN, retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref> [[David Klingler]] took over for Ware at UH and was the sixth overall pick in the [[1992 NFL Draft]]. He too, failed to find exceptional success in the NFL.<ref name="tsn"/>
==Usage== Recently, the appellation was commonly applied to [[Texas Tech Red Raiders football|Texas Tech]] quarterbacks that operated under former head coach [[Mike Leach (American football coach)|Mike Leach]] and offensive coordinator [[Dana Holgorsen]]'s [[spread offense]]. In the 2000s, the school had several different quarterbacks that threw in excess of 4,000 yards in a season. According to some pundits, this demonstrated that the quarterback had simply been an interchangeable part in a prolific passing offense. Some Texas Tech quarterbacks, with their college tenure in parentheses, described as such include: *[[Sonny Cumbie]] (2001–2004), threw for 4,742 yards his senior year.<ref name="dallas"/><ref name="dallas 1-23-09">[http://www.dallasnews.com/sharedcontent/dws/spt/colleges/texastech/stories/012309dnsposeniorlede.3af0bf5.html Quarterbacks Harrell, Bomar are battling perception], ''Dallas Morning News'', January 23, 2009.</ref><ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/player/profile?playerId=118210 Sonny Cumbie Stats], ESPN, retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref> *[[Graham Harrell]] (2004–2008), threw for 4,555, 5,705, and 5,111 yards his last three years.<ref name="dallas 1-23-09"/><ref name="pro"/><ref name="SI">[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2009/writers/bucky_brooks/02/10/qbs/ '09 NFL draft: Top 10 QB prospects], ''Sports Illustrated'', February 12, 2009.</ref><ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/player/profile?playerId=160425 Graham Harrell Stats], ESPN, retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref> *[[Cody Hodges]] (2001–2005), threw for 4,238 yards his senior year.<ref name="dallas 1-23-09"/><ref name="pro"/><ref>[http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/player/profile?playerId=118234 Cody Hodges Stats], ESPN, retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref> *[[Kliff Kingsbury]] (1998–2002), passed for 4,642 yards his senior year.<ref name="dallas 1-23-09"/><ref name="pro">[http://www.profootballweekly.com/PFW/NFLDraft/Draft+Extras/2008/harrell070408.htm Shaking the 'system' label] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081011221650/http://www.profootballweekly.com/PFW/NFLDraft/Draft+Extras/2008/harrell070408.htm |date=2008-10-11 }}, ''Pro Football Weekly'', July 5, 2008.</ref><ref>[http://texastech.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/mtt/kingsbury_kliff00.html Player Bio: Kliff Kingsbury], Texas Tech University, retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref> *[[B.J. Symons]] (2000–2003), threw for 5,336 yards his senior year.<ref name="dallas 1-23-09"/><ref name="pro"/><ref>[http://texastech.cstv.com/sports/m-footbl/stats/2003-2004/teamcume.html Cumulative Season Statistics], Texas Tech University, 2003, retrieved February 14, 2009.</ref>
The label is not restricted to Texas Tech, however, and pundits and coaches have referred to players from several other schools as benefiting from systems. In 2007, then Hawaii head coach and offensive coordinator [[June Jones]] infamously defended his own alleged system quarterback, Colt Brennan, by making the counter-accusation against Tim Tebow of Florida.<ref name="espn"/> Players from schools other than Texas Tech that were described as system quarterbacks include: *[[Colt Brennan]] – [[Hawaii Warriors football|Hawaii]] (2005–2007), under June Jones's [[Run & Shoot|run and shoot offense]].<ref name="espn"/> *[[Timmy Chang]] – Hawaii (2000–2004), under June Jones's run and shoot.<ref name="dallas"/> *[[Chase Daniel]] – [[Missouri Tigers football|Missouri]] (2005–2008), under [[Dave Christensen]]'s spread offense.<ref name="espn"/> *[[Dennis Dixon]] – [[Oregon Ducks football|Oregon]] (2003–2007), under [[Mike Belloti]]'s spread offense.<ref name="espn"/> *[[David Klingler]] – [[Houston Cougars football|Houston]] (1988–1991), under [[John Jenkins (American football coach)|John Jenkins]]'s run and shoot.<ref name="dallas"/><ref name="tsn"/> *[[Kevin Kolb]] – Houston (2003–2006), under [[Art Briles]]'s spread offense.<ref name="tsn">Russ Lande, [http://www.sportingnews.com/yourturn/viewtopic.php?t=252533 A 'system QB' in Hawaii? Not Brennan], ''The Sporting News'', August 8, 2007.</ref><ref>John Murphy, [https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl/news?slug=jm-quarterbacks021507&prov=yhoo&type=lgns Rating the quarterbacks], Yahoo! Sports, February 15, 2007.</ref> *[[Tim Tebow]] – [[Florida Gators football|Florida]] (2006–2009), 2007 [[Heisman Trophy]] winner, under [[Dan Mullen]]'s spread option.<ref name="espn"/> *[[Gino Torretta]] – [[Miami Hurricanes football|Miami]] (1989–1992), 1992 Heisman Trophy winner, under [[Bob Bratkowski]]'s [[Pro style offense|pro-style offense]].<ref name="espn"/> *[[Andre Ware]] – Houston (1987–1989), 1989 Heisman Trophy winner, under John Jenkins's run and shoot offense.<ref name="espn"/><ref name="tsn"/> *[[Connor Halliday]] – [[Washington State University]] (2011–2014), under [[Mike Leach (American football coach)|Mike Leach]]'s spread offense in his years post-Texas Tech. Tom Brady <ref>http://espn.go.com/blog/pac12/post/_/id/79040/connor-hallidays-historic-year-hidden-but-not-unnoticed</ref> The derivative and complementary term "system receiver" has been used to describe [[wide receiver]]s under similar circumstances. [[Wes Welker]] of Texas Tech and the New England Patriots is one example.<ref name="pro"/>

{{expand language|topic=|langcode=IT|otherarticle=Trampolino Giuseppe Dal Ben|date=March 2015}} {{unreferenced|date=March 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox ski jumping hill | hill_name = Trampolino Giuseppe dal Ben | nickname = Trampolino dal Ben | image = [[File:Trampolino Giuseppe dal Ben 2012-18.JPG|300px|Trampolino Giuseppe dal Ben]] | caption = | location = | city = [[Predazzo]] | country = {{Flagicon|ITA}} [[Italy]] | opened = 1988 | renovated = 2001 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | size = | k-spot = K-95
K-120 | hill size = HS106
HS134 | hill record = {{Flagicon|DEU}} [[Eric Frenzel]] (138.5 m in 2013)
{{Flagicon|AUT}} [[Christoph Bieler]] (109.5 m in 2013) | championships = | olympics = | world championships = [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1991|1991]], [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2003|2003]], [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2013|2013]] | world cup = 1990, 1991, 1992, 1993, 1995, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2001, 2008, 2012 | grand prix = 1994, 1996, 1997, 1998, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006 | universiade = [[2013 Winter Universiade|2013]] }} The '''"Giuseppe Dal Ben" Ski Jump Arena''' (''Trampolino "Giuseppe Dal Ben"'') is a [[ski jumping]] venue in [[Predazzo]], [[Val di Fiemme]], [[Trentino]], in northern [[Italy]]. It is a venue in the [[International Ski Federation|FIS]] [[Ski jumping World Cup]]. ==History== Opened in 1989, the venue hosted the [[ski jumping]] and [[nordic combined]] events of three editions of [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships]] ([[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 1991|1991]], [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2003|2003]], [[FIS Nordic World Ski Championships 2013|2013]]), of [[2013 Winter Universiade]], as well as many events of the [[Ski jumping World Cup]]. ==Venue== The {{convert|3000|m|ft}} area consists of two main [[ski jumping hill]]s (HS 134 and HS 106), other training hills (K35 and K62) and facilities for athletes, judges, federations, journalists, media, and spectators. The hills are covered with ceramic material and landing areas are covered with plastic material, guaranteeing the functionality throughout the year also in summer. The lighting system also allows competitions events by night. The main building hosts also the Organising Committee of the cross-country ski event "[[Marcialonga]]", that every January passes through the arena. The nearby [[gondola lift]] complex runs to the slopes of [[Ski Center Latemar]] in winter, and in summer to the alpine trails on the mountain [[Latemar]], part of the UNESCO world heritage site of [[Dolomites]]. ==Records== ===Large hill=== {| class="wikitable sortable" !#!!Day!!Year!!Athlet!!Result!!Event |- |1||10 February||1991||{{Flagicon|YUG}} [[Franci Petek]]||125.0 m||[[FIS Nordic World
